But one day Signor Canonic1 was having a chat In Naples with an old
Italian railway employee who was a convinced Communist* Signor
Canonic 1 says of the conversation * ”1 answered many questions which he
(meaning the Communist railway worker) asked me with a lively curiosity on the
conditions In the United States. He mentally compared what I told him about
America with the conditions which he thought existed in Russia. At the end,
after I had skimmed over the subjects of federal government benefits for
veterans, progressive taxes, TVA and other things, he (the dommuniat worker)
concluded: “Allora, in the United States there is also communism — but
white communism. ”
And Signor Canonic! adds* * Arbitrarily, I adopted this tern of 'white
communism' in place of the many others suggested, 'white communism' because
its ultimate end is that of equality, such as the ideal aim of communism was
to have been. Equality • • • without the red color of a revolution, without
the spilling of blood, only one party, and the suppression of the most ele¬
mental liberties of thought and speech.’*
Like Signor Continl, in II Meaaad^erp, Signor Canonic! is impressed by
the American graduated system of income taxes. He says that no country in
the world, excluding perhaps Great Britain, has a tax system so well conceived
from the standpoint of equalising incomes. And it impresses this Italian that
rich Americans who try to evade their income taxes go to Jail along with the
poor; the celebrities along with the unknowns.
But Signor Canonic! is impressed by many other features of the userlean
system i oocial security, government responsibility for finding Jobs for un¬
employed; old-age pensions; farm price, support programs; the spectacular
growth of free, independent labor unions; veterans* benefits; the Tennessee
Valley authority.
This, he says, is “not capitalism.* The classical school of capitalism
that Mam Smith and the Manchester school described in their treatises “does
not exist in the United States.” Signor Canonic! calls it “white communism,
and he describes it in these words* . .a scheme without a scheme, a
movement which has no rigid ideology; which can mold and modify according to
momentary circumstances.”
He says this system Is characterised by *d continuous work of moderni¬
sation, restoration and amendment to the old system.” Private initiative, he
says, “continues to be the fulcrum of the national life, but to it is added
the work of the state to protect the interests of the people and to prevent
excesses. • .”
Signor Canoniel predicts that the march forward of the American system
will be long. He says the “expectations for the success of this new experi¬
ment seem good.”
One of the reasons why h© believes the prospects are good is the behavior
of the Eisenhower administration with respect to the economic and social pro¬
gram of the Hew Deal, launched by President Roosevelt more than 20
years ago.
Signor Canonic! says that in many European circles the election of a
Republican candidate was interpreted as ”a repudiation of the work accomplish¬
ed in 20 years of a Democratic majority; a backward step in respect to the
social politics of the Hew Deal and the Fair Deal.” But Jlgnor Canonic! be¬
lieves that the victory of Eisenhower instead represented, in effect, a rati¬
fication of the preceding work. He says* ”Elsenhower never thought of reque¬
